message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant is displaying symptoms of neonatal abstinence syndrome, which can occur when a baby is exposed to opioids in utero. Morphine is the standard treatment for neonatal abstinence syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of the infant suggest narcotic withdrawal, likely due to maternal opioid use during pregnancy. Morphine is the necessary pharmacological treatment to alleviate the withdrawal symptoms. Acetaminophen is for pain relief, naloxone is for opioid overdose, and phenobarbital is to treat seizures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms in the infant suggest that the baby may be experiencing opioid withdrawal, which is a potential complication of maternal opioid use during pregnancy. Morphine can be used to taper the baby off the opioids gradually, reducing withdrawal symptoms. Acetaminophen is not a treatment for opioid withdrawal. Naloxone is used to reverse opioid overdose, but is not appropriate in this case. Phenobarbital is used to treat neonatal seizures, which are not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of the infant suggest neonatal withdrawal syndrome. The treatment for this syndrome is morphine, which can reduce the symptoms of withdrawal and prevent seizures. Acetaminophen is not indicated for this condition, and naloxone is used for opioid overdose. Phenobarbital is used for seizure control but not for neonatal withdrawal syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of the newborn suggest neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) which occurs in infants born to mothers who used opioids during pregnancy. The necessary pharmacological treatment for NAS is morphine. Acetaminophen and phenobarbital are not indicated for NAS, and naloxone may be used if the newborn is experiencing respiratory depression.

We refer to Medscape articles on obstetrics and pediatrics for help. The symptoms suggest neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) due to maternal opioid use during pregnancy. Morphine is the preferred first-line medication for NAS. Acetaminophen is not indicated for NAS, naloxone may be used in cases of respiratory depression, and phenobarbital is not recommended as first-line treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant's symptoms suggest that withdrawal symptoms related to opioid exposure may be present, which is common in babies born to mothers with opioid use disorders. Morphine is used as a treatment for neonatal abstinence syndrome. Acetaminophen is a pain reliever but will not address the withdrawal symptoms. Naloxone is used to reverse an opioid overdose. Phenobarbital is used to treat seizures and may be used in neonatal abstinence syndrome, but it is not the first-line treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms in the infant suggest neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS), which is caused by withdrawal from opioids. As the patient denies using any substances, it is likely that the infant was exposed through in utero transfer. Morphine is the pharmacological treatment of choice for NAS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant’s symptoms suggest neonatal abstinence syndrome, which can occur in infants exposed to opioids in utero. The necessary pharmacological treatment is morphine, which is used to wean the infant off of opioids to prevent withdrawal symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the infant suggest opioid withdrawal, which can be treated with Morphine. Naloxone is used to treat opioid overdose, and phenobarbital is used for seizures. Acetaminophen is not indicated for this scenario.
